review_title: Open to feedback and constantly improving
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The higher-up’s here have an open-door policy and welcome any and all criticism. If you have something to say, they want to hear it and if your advice is actionable, they’ll take it into consideration. I’ve been with Westchester for almost 4 years and I always felt like the bosses treat everyone fairly and with the same consideration and respect that they expect from us in return.
cons: There are always issues occasionally (just like at any job), but what makes Westchester special is their dedication to listening to the staff and ensuring that they do everything they can to make sure our issues are resolved.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: The staff are incredibly warm and welcoming. This is easily the most comfortable I’ve personally felt in a professional work environment. No one is going to hold your hand but they also won’t let you flounder on your own either. The resources and support are readily available to help you succeed. I’ve never had any issues with any of the students and every semester I’m here I look forward to all the happy, bright-eyed students I get to meet and teach.
cons: It takes a minute to find a sustainable work/life balance. I’ve bene here over two years and I still don’t always have the level of consistency I’m looking for. I think that may come with being a professor, though, and isn’t specific to Westchester.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: I have been a professor for 7 years and I’ve spent two of them here. Of my 7 years of experience, teaching here has easily been the best choice. The students are driven, respectful, and kind. They make coming to work every day an absolute treat. The staff is also mission-aligned and extremely caring about their students. The support team also is deeply invested in your personal development and will do whatever they can to help you achieve your goals. I can't wait to continue my career here. 100% would recommend.
cons: We spend a lot of time setting our students up for success.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The work environment here is very professional and organized. I have no complaints about the way the school is run or how they conduct their business. The workload can be intense at first depending on your position, but you get used to it after a while and things start to feel more manageable. The coworkers are great, even if people don’t get along they always set aside their personal feelings and try to be polite and respectful. I’ve never been disrespected or talked down to by anyone here. The benefits and pay here are excellent as well - they’re honestly much higher than I was expecting.
cons: The only thing I can think of is the initial work-life balance when you first start, but it really just depends on your position and your willingness to work with your higher-ups to figure out what’s best for you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: This college is full of people who are constantly working towards a shared mission: supporting and loving students. We strive to both love our kids and hold them to high expectations - the "and" is the important part. Too often schools operate as if those two things are mutually exclusive, when in reality they are not. Westchester supports teachers in finding the "and" and doing the work they love at the highest level
cons: Because of the high level of commitment, the job can be stressful and the hours can be long (but it's worth it)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I’ve only been working for the college for a few months now. My first impression has been good for the most part. My coworkers all seem friendly and are happy to help me any time I have a question. The work environment is healthy and encouraging, and the pay is generous. I love working with the students and seeing them grow over time.
cons: I don’t think I’ve been here long enough to speak at any length on the negatives of working here because I haven’t really experienced any. So far things have been good and I’m satisfied with my role and what’s expected of me on a day-to-day basis.

job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Preparing young people for beneficial, productive careers and lives is important and you know that what you do matters. Compared to other professions, you have a lot of freedom to decide what you do and how you do it beyond your basic teaching responsibilities. There were always stimulating, smart people around to talk with. For associate professors in particular, there was always a lot of encouragement and support. The college was transparent about advancement and opportunities for tenure.
cons: Can feel bureaucratic from time to time, but I think you’d be hard-pressed to find a successful college that doesn’t have that feeling.

review_title: Working hard to improve diversity policies
job_title: Associate Advisor in New York, NY
pros: It doesn’t matter who you are, where you came from, what your religion, or identification status is, everyone is welcome and respected here at Westchester! The diversity, equality, and inclusion initiatives are being driven from all sorts of individuals throughout the staff, with people of very diverse backgrounds and different departments all having a say in how they think the college should be run. I’m so proud to be working for a company that truly welcomes diversity.
cons: None to speak of at this time!

job_title: Admissions Counselor in New York, NY
pros:
The people who work here were the best part of the job. There’s something about the college that just attracts the most intelligent, positive, creative people. It made for one of the best work environments I’ve ever experienced. 

The students I interacted with all seemed like good people. Seeing them grow and learn so much from their attendance here made my life feel more meaningful.
cons: I have absolutely nothing negative to say. It just wasn’t the right place for me long-term.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Not only is this an excellent school, but staff members genuinely care of each other and their students. Westchester is a highly personable, caring environment for both staff and students.
cons: The expectations for both students and staff are incredibly high. This leads to excellence, and can also lead to teacher burnout if systems are not in place by individual teachers to ensure life balance.

job_title: Associate Advisor in New York, NY
pros: One of those jobs that’s mostly ideal for individuals who want to be here. Westchester has a lot to offer but isn’t a walk in the park either. It can be tough sometimes (as I’m sure you’ve seen from the various reviews on this page). I’ve been having a great time personally. I love the camaraderie I’ve built with my co-workers.
cons: We have our problems but the leadership do their best to face these problems head on.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Students get a more personalized experience. Small classes allow for professors to meet the needs of each student in their care. The environment is opening to everyone. The building is clean. Everyone I work with personally cares about their job and want to see students succeed. Most ideal if you’re just getting started out and you need experience on your resume. There’s a lot to learn.
cons: I don’t have any cons.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
*Excellent colleagues
*Great students
*Collaborative work environment 
*Great campus 
*Great job flexibility 
*Good benefits (health insurance, retirement plans, etc.) 
*Excellent interdisciplinary resources, although some departments are better than others 
*Meaningful work
cons: Depends on the department you work for, mine had no issues

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Everyone actually follows through on all their commitments and promises
Everyone is exemplary in their roles
Growth mindset is the norm, not perfectionism
Self-reflection is built into procedures and systems
Expectations are clear and well supported
cons: -It's a lot of work, but so is most work in education

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good pay and the work environment is easy to get acclimated to. All staff are held to a high standard and while this can be stressful, it also ensures that the students are being served by the best people suited for the job. I recommend College of Westchester.
cons: Morale has its ups and downs.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in White Plains, NY
pros: Great employees make a fun work environment.
cons: The hours are very difficult.

job_title: Associate Professor in Edison, NJ
pros: Faculty go the Extra Mile
cons: Faculty are not valued for the very challenging work that they contribute.

review_title: I still have PTSD a year later
job_title: Admissions Advisor in White Plains, NY
pros: Pay was higher than average but at the cost of your mental health and sanity
cons: This place really knows how to get you. While you're interviewing you're under the illusion that you're going to be part of this wonderful family and that you're going to be making a positive impact on young students lives', while making a good salary.  This couldn't be farther from the truth. The admissions department is one of the most toxic work environments you will ever encounter. There is blatant favoritism in the department and micro management to the point where management will count and time your bathroom breaks (but this doesn't apply to the favorites of course) The work hours are long usually there are two days per week where you are expected to work from 11am-9pm but there are so many rules as to when you can take breaks sometimes you go without one. For example: You are not allowed to take your break after 3pm so that means that unless you packed a dinner too you will be hungry until 10pm when you get home. The job itself also makes you feel like a fraud. You are expected to enroll a certain amount of students each semester but its often too difficult to sell such an expensive college with mediocre services without feeling like you're ripping the students off.   (The college is 1 single small building).  This job made me feel anxious, pressured, stressed and guilty the entire time.  My mental health was at an all time low when I worked here.

review_title: Amazing Faculty and Staff, poor benefits and incentives
job_title: Administrative Assistant in White Plains, NY
pros: Friendly people, caring president and great students.  A joy to work in an environment where staff and faculty really care.
cons: Salary freezes have been going on for years and are very discouraging as the cost of living continues to increase.

review_title: For Profit Education Having Rough Times
job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Plains, NY
pros: Lovely people to work with who truly care about one another. Very small location with even fewer employees after a recent reduction in force.  Small number of students to support and serve, and classes Monday-Thursday - very few on Fridays.
cons: Stability of the institution is questionable considering the fate of for-profit institutions.  Enrollment is dropping consistently and recent layoff leaves the remaining staff and students feeling vulnerable.

review_title: Good Place to get your feet wet....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Plains, NY
pros: Just getting started with your career this would be a great place to start. Most of the staff is great. Building is always kept clean. Small class sizes. Professors really care....
cons:
Being a for profit institution in this day and age is crucial to anyone's career. Admission tactics have been very aggressive to bring anyone is to the school. No matter their educational or financial background. This is due to the low enrollments. 
Also you may come to work and find out you have to take on someone else's duties from then on out plus your regular duties without extra pay. Job titles change to make you feel special. Facilities staff very unprofessional as they like to flirt with staff and students. 
Management doesn't show care for your outside life as schedule is not very flexible.

job_title: Assistant Professor in White Plains, NY
pros: Get to do the work you love and make a difference.
cons: Management is less than nurturing.  Very hierarchical culture.  Communication from management to employees often lacks respect.  Emphasis is on revenue.  Benefits are poor.  Salary freeze for several years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Most of the staff and faculty are graduates of the College. 
Provide many opportunities for Professional developmment.
cons:
No opportunity to grow. 
Very generic job titles.

job_title: in White Plains, NY
pros: they offer payment for hours worked
cons: This school is a for profit school which is a big problem when students are pulling out loans for $20K plus a year for a school that is smaller than most Walmarts. I worked in the "call center" where you listen to voicemail's for hours at a time in hopes of getting someone on the phone, who most likely never requested information since they pay for names, to convince them to come in to see the "campus." I was told that if 20% of your appointments set show up for their visit that's a great percentage and seen as successful. Employees in the Admissions department sleep, eat, watch movies, and shop at their desks all day while "working" and then management gets annoyed with potential students not coming in. They complain about numbers but never offer training or guidance on how to improve as an employee. Management does not know how to motivate or engage employees and its not a positive environment. For young professionals its a joke and they have the audacity to require you to have a college degree to work there and they pull your transcript, I was so offended. The school is a joke and not a great education.  When it comes to the "budget" you can be let go of at anytime because they suddenly don't have money for your position, and then they may call you back to offer you a part time position.  Management told me to attempt to belittle potential students in order to get them to think about college "tell them that working at Bed Bath and Beyond is not a good goal, we can help you" Its hard to sell a dream you don't believe in especially when you call students that are in debit because of the school that promised them jobs.

review_title: Family environment, however no room for growth.
job_title: Office Assistant in White Plains, NY
pros: The colleagues were nice, the company feels like a little family because it is a small school. Pretty flexible in terms of work scheduling.
cons: There is little to No room for growth. additional responsibilities are added to your daily tasks without any formal change in job responsibilities

job_title: Admissions Advisor in White Plains, NY
pros: Warning: DO NOT WORK HERE.
cons:
- College rips off students 
- limited programs and incentives for students 
- Admissions counselors are fake and catty people 
- management only care about money and getting tons of LEADS
- They only promote college alumni's 
- no opportunity for growth 
- there are so many rumors that full time employees sleep with other employees and yet they continue to work there. 
- mangement do not provide any development or training skills 
- this college is a joke

job_title: in Monroe, NY
pros: They had friendly faculty and staff. I had a fun job.
cons: They downsized a lot and went on a few pay freezes when I worked there.

job_title: Student Worker in New York, NY
pros: Awesome Job and Flexible
cons: Minimun wage and limit on how much you can earn

job_title: Evening Book Store Clerk in White Plains, NY
pros: Good job stability with many additional perks.
cons: Not enough people leave to create promotion opportunities.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in White Plains, NY
pros: Supportive deans. Great holiday party to show appreciation to staff!
cons: A very challenging environment at times.
